And so I always find a major, uh, under the auspices of an intellectual conversation,
there's really an emotional conversation or at least an emotional exchange that needs to occur.
And what happened and I, you say this and people think, Oh, it stops, like,
Oh, analyzing mere stop reducing me or telling me my own experience. But, you know,
I'm not going to turn my own brain off or have my own emotional reactions. I've heard a lot of these
stories and a lot of times it sounds like something painful happened. And, um, there, the, the, the
painful reaction happened first. And then intellectual arguments were hung upon this
that came second. Um, but when the church constitutionally can and cannot accept or at
least acknowledge the pain that it has caused, right? Um, because what that person heard was not
that they weren't allowed to have a doubt or a question. What they heard was that they were
wrong to have a doubt or a question and that they were sort of judged for it. And, um, that is that
produces judgment tends to not produce what it calls for. I think the, the law kind of
interests increases the trespass in these situations. So I am always looking for, when I hear these,
uh, an atheist speak, um, uh, you know, I, I just, that's such an ironclad position. I always want
to wonder what their experience of life is actually like because so much of our lives are
unclear and wrapped up in mystery. And when we're a mystery to ourselves and to have that sort of
clarity, I find my faith allows me that to, to sit in that kind of, um, uh, both and I guess,
or the conundrum, I call it the book. I wrote Doubleness that I'm two things at once. Uh,
and I, that's one of the reasons I find the Christianity so compelling in a lot of ways
is that it allows me not to that, um, I, there's a God and I'm not, Hey, you know, so I can,
I can kind of rest in that as to, to borrow that resting language. Uh, and yet,
yeah. So to feel like I have to have a complete 110% commitment to this one area, it feels
antithetical to actual life, but emotions and hurts and wounds can be so deep. And if they,
especially if they happen at a certain age in our lives, you know, um, that it can inform the rest
of your life, just like someone who spends all of their, their entire life trying to prove something
to their dad, even if they're, their father's dead, you know, you know, Matt, just say that what it's,
if it's a heavenly father, you know, it's, it's Stalin, you know, shaking his fist at God before
the God that he doesn't believe it right before he dies. I think that's a lot of fuel. Yeah.
But if I think about it in terms of pain or a cry for help, then I can have compassion and,
and rather than, uh, come at them with the same judgment that they've already experienced.
That was, it is intriguing the way that, that, uh, his name is David as well,
Smalley and I met was that at an Easter service, I, I years ago now, probably a long time ago,
I had lamented that I had been trying to be invited to any of the free thinker associations
in East Texas. Like just let me come, I'll answer questions. I'll sit on the stage. I'll
do whatever you want. I just want to, I would love to answer questions so that you to see,
you know, what questions you have. I want to understand you better and, and what your
perspectives are. And none of them would let me come. Like I was strictly forbidden. Like they
told me, if you show up, we will tell you to leave. Like I was like, I think your definition
of free thinking is different than mine. Like I, I think that's, that's an intriguing way to deal
with it. And that didn't change anything. And then, so David contacted me at a nationally
known atheist. And we talked online several times and we had him come to the church and the podcast,
but I agree with you. That's, that's absolutely the case. And, and again, it comes back to that.
I think you're more somehow, you're more certain as to your irreligious perspective
than I've ever been to my religious perspective. Like you have, yeah, there's a few things I have
colored in pretty with, with a high degree of confidence, but a lot of the rest of it is,
I'm still, I'm still learning all the time, how wrong I am about things. And so, um, anyway,
so I, I, this was through these conversations as kind of how we created this. I would love to hear
David, was there a time that you feel like that was there a narrow miss for you in regards to,
um, man, I feel like I could have easily gotten stuck here. Um, and what, and what helped you in
that? Like, what was your, what was the toughest thing for you as you've lived out this life
and but stayed with true to the, the faith that you called to?
Well, the hardest thing for me, I think the hardest, it's the hardest thing for a lot of
people of Christians. Um, it's other Christians. I mean, that's like the,
it's other people. I mean, that's the hardest thing about being alive, basically. Um, but I
would say the church and being not just disappointed by the church, but actively
antagonized by the church in certain ways, opposed and to feel like the church is this
organization, this institution that's supposed to be the bride of Christ acting in ways that seem
like, you know, frankly, diabolical. Um, that's very, very challenging. I mean, it's not,
I'm not just talking about someone telling me I need to vote for the different person. You know,
I'm talking about the abuse, uh, of like the, you know, whether that be sort of child abuse or
spousal abuse or, uh, you know, just the way that that, that power has worked out its way out in,
in church structures, I find to be enormously, enormously, um, dispiriting as a, as a person
who loves Jesus and, uh, venerates the Bible. And so as, as, as you get older, you're sort of like,
what is this institution that I'm propping up in, or is that what I'm doing? It's gotta be more than
that. And I, I find that, that, that the gospel, that Jesus himself, God's experience of God is, uh,
something that has, uh, sustaining relevance and, uh, of ultimate relevance, in fact, in our lives.
And the times when I've taken my eyes off of that and put my hope or trust in this particular
Christian project or voice or a church, I've found it dispiriting to the point of wanting to just have
nothing to do with it. And I, and I, so I, I understand that and I'm not, I understand it
actively in that like I've, I'm not ordained, like, and I'm surrounded by people who are ordained,
um, you know, and, and are clergy. And I have, I've got my tang ups run so deep that I can't
associate myself any more further than I already have. So, um, yeah, that's, that's an actively
ongoing, ongoing thing when you, when you read about, you know, those, those, and, and that's,
so I, I guess, um, and also, you know, it's not just sort of the abuses in the Catholic Church
or something or reading about, you know, the latest clergy, the mega church pastor who's
fallen down. I, I do, um, stay attuned to the cycles of shame and, um, abs and, and hiddenness,
you know, sort of hiding that certain forms of evangelicalism have really inculcated in
generations of people such that they want anything but that, like that's, that's, that's, you know,
that's kind of what the free thinkers society is saying, like that, I want anything but that. And
I think to myself, gosh, my experience of the, the, the God has been as a good news and a comfort
and has not been, and so far away from anything but that as you get older and you continue to
hear horror stories of how people, you know, when they most needed mercy, they were met with
the exact opposite by someone claiming to represent Jesus. It's, it's, if you're a feeling person,
you just eventually, there's like maybe the structure or the whole thing is just,
um, let's, let's, let's walk away. Let's walk away. And I, so I have tremendous sympathy with, uh,
with people who've done that. And, um, I just want to say that, like, that's not,
but it wasn't for me, you know, I, I know that I am also surrounded by people who are like, well,
the second so-and-so got elected, that's when I knew, you know, that was just a bridge too far.
And I'm just not a very political person. Um, so that wasn't for me. And I, you know, the, the
things like the resurrection, that wasn't, um, I, I, there's so much to my own life that I can't
explain. And, and I'm so skeptical of the, or so, so, uh, aware of the limits of reason, um, when
it comes to human life, you know, um, so much of what I value about being alive has nothing to do
with logic, you know, it, and I'm talking about invisible forces like the soul, uh, love, uh,
forgiveness. These, these things I think operate outside of, um, you know, the, the curse of, of
being born to a certain type of parent, you know, the, the, there's so much to me that the most
important things in life that are still the things that are dealt with in the Bible and are, you know,
that are addressed by God. Um, so that was never, uh, I was never, it wasn't like an apologetic
argument that I needed to have as much more of the experiential one of being like, how is this
thing enabling these people to be so awful? Um, and, and, you know, I, I do think though, I mean,
I, I think that people will, if they want to do something awful, they'll find a way to justify it.
And if they use religious language to do it, they'll use religious language. If they use political
language to do it, they'll use that if they want to use economic language to do it that. So I, I
really think that, um, uh, if you grow up only in that world and you think, well, it's, it's the
religion is the problem or the religious language is the problem. Once you get out, you're like,
wait a second. People are still acting like self-interested so-and-so's. They're using
something else to justify it. And, um, it turns out my experience of human beings, uh, is much more,
um, I guess universal than, um, uh, so that's, that's what I'd say about that.
I have a question, David. So as, and I agree with you, so, but as with all that being true,
what's something that's kept you actively involved in participating in like the church body in spite
of that? Um, what's, what's something that's kept you motivated to still be a part of it?
For me, it's, it comes down to a couple of different things, uh, relationships, uh, you know,
that my, the, uh, our pastor or our rector is a wonderful, wonderful man of God. And he's,
I think is, um, not out for himself and not on some large ego trip and, uh, is genuinely
interested in proclaiming the gospel to a hurting world. And like that is, that's the disposition.
That's the emotional temperature of the church. Um, it's a very, I'd say robust faith. You know,
it's a, uh, we were clinging to an old tradition, but, um, that is super compelling and he's been
there and shown up for me when really not just difficult, awful things have happened, you know,
and I've seen the true colors shine through and I've seen that this is not, he's not just talking
about it. Um, so I'd say that relationships are hugely important in that. I also, you know, I,
I, I, the liturgy that we do at our church is from, you know, it was written in the 16th century and
it's, it connects me with something larger than just this current moment. And as our kind of
temporal bandwidth shrinks, you know, our ability to remember beyond the last five minutes, I find
that to be deeply countercultural, the allowance for silence, for rest, for, um, these virtues that
I think have been largely lost. Um, and for which I crave, uh, and the, the, the allowance to feel sad,
to be honest, to bring my real self to God. Uh, but ultimately, Bryn, I mean, the real question is like,
do I have, do I experience God? Do I, do I, do I come into, do I, do I meet with God in, at church?
And, you know, maybe it's just the, the ultimate evidence of God's grace that he continues to work
through something as broken and in many ways terrible as the church. So, I mean, but that also
means maybe that means he could use me too. Yeah. Yeah. I think that's the fascinating thing about
your answers. Like, even though so much of, um, the thing that's been difficult has been people
at the same time, some of the hope that you've found in that is through people, like in relationships
and people who are, who are demonstrating an authentic faith, even, you know, not perfect,
but authentic. That's, that's fascinating. Go ahead. Sorry. No, at the end of the day,
we're still talking about forgiveness every, every Sunday. And that's the central things like this.
God not only loves you, God forgives you. And like that is, um, in a, in a culture that feels less and
less forgiving. And it's so many of these affinity groups that where you can find some belonging,
where you can find some community, ultimately become, uh, purity spirals, you know, like the,
the church's caricature is being, but is often experienced is not actually, at least the church
I've, I've experienced. I find that, um, anywhere that's talking about forgiveness, um, is, is going
to feel a little different. Um, at least it has for me. Um, and so at least that's, you can't really
get away from that. If you're trying to be a Christian in any kind of, uh, uh, substantial way,
any kind of biblical way. Yeah. It's intriguing that we, what one of our themes that we keep
coming back to is the need for us to, um, kind of deconstruct our faith in humans, especially
ourselves. Um, and I want to come back to that in a minute, because I do want to reference the,
the book that you recently published that I was, that I got to hear you speak about. Um,
but, but one of the things that stands out to me is I've, in this conversation,
we've talked about how removing, for example, removing God from a suffering and evil world
does not reduce the amount of evil and suffering in the world. It just reduces any hope of redemption
of that evil and suffering. And in the same way, so when people say the problem of evil, you know,
how's their evil, if there's a, if there's God, and I'm like, I sure don't want to face that evil
without God. That seems like a bad choice. Um, because the evil is not going anywhere and the
suffering is not going anywhere. And so, um, anyway, but what the way you answered that struck me that
the same thing would be say removing yourself from the church does not remove the pain that
humans can and will cause us. It just, it just means we have a less redemptive place to engage
with that. Um, unless a less potentially meaningful place to engage in that. It just,
I had not put those pieces together as well. I really, that stands out as significant.
And your point that I thought was really insightful about, um, I think you said something to the
effect of, um, the way that power has worked itself, worked its way in use in the church. And that's
really insightful of the same thing to your point, Chris, is it's not that everyone in the church is
even authentically following the Lord, but it's like, we're all broken people and people will use
power to abuse others. And unfortunately that also means in the church as a, as a body. Um,
but if we understand that and we have that under that, that insight to know, like we're broken
people, even in the church, um, there is abuse and power that's misused because it's full of broken
humans. And that doesn't have a, that more speaks to what we're like as humans than the body of
Christ and the church that God designed and how he, he wants for us to interact in the world. Um,
anyway, I thought that was, that's wild. Yeah. That's significant. Well, and religious language
is an extremely potent weapon, uh, or, or tool, shall we say it can for good and for ill. Right.
Um, it's, you know, you're, you're using the, the threat of a hellfire. You can, um, you can get
people to follow you for a little while. Um, you know, that's, that's a very, that's a little
different than certain other communities where those things aren't at play. Um, but that means
it's just that much more prone to abuse. Um, and as we've seen, but, and yet again, you know, where,
to whom else shall we go? Uh, that's the great question. I was just listening to a talk about it
and where else am I, uh, do I hear about God that created me knows me and yet still loves me and
wants to be involved in actual, um, you know, my actual life rather than some ideal version of my
life. I think that's, that's still to me. Um, the great question of being alive, um, is forgiveness
possible. Um, and, uh, and, and, and what, what about when we die, what's going on? The two great
questions in life to me are the guilt question and the death question. And, um, I feel so very
strongly that Christianity, the, the, the Bible, that Jesus Christ has a lot to say about those
things, which I, um, the, the answers I'm given are not, um, uh, trite or, uh, yes, too easy or,
they're not, they're not, yeah, they're not reductive. They're not there. They're this sort
of well that you can continue to go back to, but those are the things I'm, I'm, to keep me up at
night or what do I do about all this? Um, my guilt. Yeah. And what about the fact that I'm going to
die? How do I handle that? And my loved ones are going to die loss. Like what do I, is there any
meaning in that? Can there be meaning in that? Those are much more powerful questions than like,
what music should I listen to? Or, you know, when is it okay to have a beer or something like that?
Yes. Yes. Those are such, such a low cal questions when he gets to what, what Christianity is really
concerned with is, is are the deepest things imaginable and yet somehow we've reduced it to
tiny, very arbitrary, um, not completely arbitrary, but in the, in many cases,
arbitrary measures of cultural righteousness that has nothing to do with where do I go when I die?
How do I, what about is love possible as forgiveness possible? How do I deal with the
fact that I'm suffering? Like these are the great questions of life. And so if you reduce that down
to what, um, you know, again, is it okay to dance, you know, when I'm 14, I think, I think you've
really sold your, your, your, your heritage for something kind of pathetic. There you go. That's a
cheap porridge right there. Yeah. That's so interesting. That's one thing we talk about with
student ministry here is how do we encourage our students to go deep and have those really hard
questions? Because I think you're right. I think when we, when we limit the conversations of faith
to something so shallow in the spectrum of, of what scripture covers in the life that God offers
for us, like you're saying, not that they're, um, completely irrelevant, but I wonder if that,
that adds to deconstruction, especially for young people of like, well, this is all that,
that churches and, and even Christianity is these conversations about like,
um, you know, behavioral modification and, and moralism and things like that, then they're
missing out on the depth of like you're saying, what faith and is and what scripture covers and
even the richness of life in Christ instead of just the, well, I have my list of things that
I'm not supposed to do. Okay. This, this, this has jumped out at me. Last week I met with the program
team, kind of the student ministry, children's ministry, uh, wing of the churches ministry and,
and it's summer. So we've got to start talking about modesty and clothing issues and et cetera.
And so the question, yeah. And so, and so what we didn't, we were like, listen, we cannot let this
become Christianity is about whether or not your fingertips or your shorts are longer. And,
and so instead, how do we turn this into a question of what does sacred mean? What does gentleness
mean? Like, how do we unpack this conversation for our kids so that they understand, listen,
this is not about the links of shorts. This is about, this is an expression of identity or
like something that really has meat to it that we can say, don't, don't see this as up. That's,
it's Christianity, which is primarily about, you know, how short my screw is.
Three and a half to five inch in seems.
Yeah, exactly. And so it's which, which again, may be a practical application of kindness or
modesty or, or sacredness, but, but to, to, like you said, to simplify the conversation down to,
no, to that's not even right. I mean, to dumb down the conversation from this,
listen, we're not just behavioral mod people here. This is, this is a cosmic conversation that we
want to be having. That's going to have some very nitty gritty practical application day to day.
Do I make my wife's side of the bed or just mine? Like that is a, that's a, that's a really dumb
conversation, but it may be an application of a massive conversation of sacrifice and it's not
about me. And, and so how do we make sure we're putting those in the right order? And I'm, I'm
totally stealing that imagery of selling our heritage for a cup of stew. Like that is,
that's exactly how that feels. Like that conversation felt like I had a whole,
there's a lineage here. The, the, the, one of us is going to be the line of the snake stomper. And
you know what? I just decided I'd rather have some porridge right now.
Yeah. And culturally speaking, you might say that we, can we really afford to bed down in those
questions? I mean, I'll tell, I mean, we can once in, in, within our communities and things like that.
And I agree a hundred percent that there's reasons why Christians believe in modesty.
Right. That's right.
It's not, it's not an, it's not meant to be a huge cruelty thing or a thing. In fact, there's,
there's love. We believe that there's sort of some, some love actually animating some of those
questions. And yet if you're, if you're nine years old and that's, that's, you receive a kind of a,
some kind of huge no about some skirt you wore by mistake. And that's that you're not going to hear
the deeper conversation. And so, and I don't want to blame those kids for that being what they heard.
Like, how do we, because a lot of it boils down to, you know, the, the reason sometimes people
get shut down is the insecurity of the pastor or the Christian. And they think that you feel
personally threatened by someone's insecure, like a problem with the faith. And I think that we,
we need to be more willing to let, to say, okay, am I only hearing some sort of threat to me or am
I hearing an actual question there? How can I engage the question while also not, not bringing my own
fears to the table? And I've found, so I was a youth minister for five years before I started
Mockingbird and it really can be, I highly suggest it to people for the sake of, I think
youth ministry is wonderful and I think it bears an amazing fruit. And I've worked with college
students here in Virginia for a long time. And I, but you know, what I found was that when I dealt
with parents, they were really predominantly concerned with two things. They were concerned
with alcohol and with sex. And like that was, and, and they really, it was, they were, yes,
they were wanted to the child to have an active relationship with Jesus Christ, but their anxiety
about those two things. I don't want them to get someone pregnant or become pregnant. And I don't
want them to have a drunk driving accident. Those are real fears of I'm a parent now and I understand
it. You, of course we want to protect people from those things, but as a result, it became, if that's
what all I was there to do was to enforce two things that would sort of almost expire when they
got married or when they turned 21, then that was a very pathetic, active, like a vocation that I was
pursuing. Yes. And what I noticed was that if I were able to give the kids to try to bring them
into the deeper questions, those conversations, even if they had a period where they said, Oh,
to hell with this, I'm not interested. I've watched as one by one, almost every single one has come
back to the faith in a meaningful way because I, for whatever reason, I felt like God answered my
prayer that I wasn't, didn't bring, I didn't shut them down. Like part of having faith that God is
in control is allowing someone to have a little bit of a wilderness period such that they might
come back for themselves. And that's not, that's not been given any kind of airing among a certain
type of clergy. Right. But I've watched, I mean, I hate, I usually am the sort of
preacher who never gives a, an illustration that makes them look good.
Because for time I thought, Oh my gosh, I'm not, I'm not toeing the line enough. I'm not coming
down on them enough about their, you know, their dating relationships or something like that.
But by keeping the conversation on life and death, the possibility of forgiveness,
the veracity of God's existence. I've just watched as when, when, when this real storms have hit
these young people who are now in their thirties, they've looked to the church to help them. Right.
Rather than as a place where they're going to get another slammed door. Yep. And it might have been,
I might've been born out of hubris when I was younger. I was afraid to have those conversations
with kids, you know, God could have used my cowardice in certain ways or culturally I knew
that I'd get in trouble if I talked too much about premarital sex or something like that.
But I just have watched that they felt like the church was a place they could go to when
problems came. And that's a beautiful thing. So you really just kind of, I mean, you might
not have liked to coin this phrase, but you focused your attention really on Christ and him crucified.
Absolutely. 100%. 100%. You should coin it to copyright that while it's still out there.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
